messageBody:
2009/6/19 William Pietri <william@...>:
>
>
>
> Hi! There's some functionality I had built for myself in the land of
> JUnit 3, and I'm trying to figure out how best to replicate it in JUnit
> 4. Let me explain it in two parts.
>
> The first part is something that finds all my tests (by walking the
> filesystem) and then runs them.
>
> The second part is a way for me to segregate different sorts of tests so
> that I can run them conditionally. I previously used annotations,
> including something akin to the @Ignore annotation that I'm pleased to
> see is now included. I also had something like @Category("slow"), which
> allowed me to kick slow tests out of the common target that developers run.
>
> For the first part, I found this chunk of code, so I didn't have to
> write that myself:
>
> http://burtbeckwith.com/blog/?p=52
>
> But now that I'm looking to add the second part to it, it seems awkward
> enough that I wonder if I'm going about it wrong.
>
> Within this structure, it looks like I could use per-class annotations
> to kick entire classes out of the set of tests to run. But is there a
> reasonable way I could use annotations on individual methods to include
> or exclude them from the set of tests to run?

Since Cedric seems to be very quiet on this list these days, let me
say that TestNG supports this [1]. I don't think I can point at JUnit
and say that it offers the same granularity to control which tests
run? Is it simple to do with a Custom Runner / Interceptor?

Cheers,

James
